key_insight: AndroidLens provides a realistic, multilingual benchmark of long‑latency mobile GUI tasks with nested sub‑targets, exposing capabilities and failures of GUI agents on multi‑step workflows (avg. >26 steps).
problem_solved: Existing GUI agent evaluations are limited to few apps, short/simple tasks, and coarse metrics; AndroidLens fills the gap by offering a large, challenging suite that measures performance on realistic, long‑horizon, hierarchical tasks in Chinese and English.
method: Curate 571 long‑latency tasks spanning common mobile apps, each decomposed into nested sub‑targets to capture hierarchical goals and dependencies.
Provide multilingual (Chinese & English) task descriptions and structured step sequences to force multi‑step planning and execution (avg. >26 steps per task).
Introduce finer‑grained evaluation metrics (e.g., sub‑target success, step‑level progress, latency/robustness) to reveal partial successes and systematic failure modes.
impact: AndroidLens enables more realistic, diagnostic evaluation of mobile GUI agents, guiding development of planners, error‑recovery, and latency‑aware policies; researchers can now benchmark robustness on truly long‑horizon, hierarchical tasks.
visual_elements: Hierarchical diagram showing a task decomposed into nested sub‑targets (root goal → subgoals → atomic steps).
Sequential timeline/flowchart illustrating a representative 26+ step long‑latency task across multiple apps.
Bar/line chart comparing AndroidLens vs prior benchmarks (num tasks, avg steps, languages, metric granularity).
Icon collage of mobile apps + bilingual labels to emphasize multilingual, cross‑app coverage.
paper_title: AndroidLens: Long-latency Evaluation with Nested Sub-targets for Android GUI Agents
paper_authors: Yue Cao, Yingyao Wang, Pi Bu, Jingxuan Xing, Wei Jiang
